title: I cannot believe that Apple has been in‚Ä¶
text: I cannot believe that Apple has been in business for so many years and still show no improvement in customer service, honesty or product innovation. I have been buying Apple products for years but I am always mortified whenever I go into the Apple Store and I have been into quite a few of them, even while abroad.  My first bad experience with Apple was when I bought my first Mac and didn't know much about the product so pretty much accepted what they gave me as the norm. I was a little bit disappointed when I got home and found out that the Mac that I had been given already had someone else's details on it. I couldn't even set up an Apple ID because it wasn't the one that had already been set up. I didn't take it back, I just didn't bother to get anything from the App Store because the Mac was mostly for work anyway. The second bad experience was when I went into an Apple Store and the music was so loud that the assistant stood directly in front of my face and shouted the answers to every question I had asked. Other people in the store were also shouting so I came out with a really bad headache. The third bad experience was discovering that Apple products are not as safe or hacker-proof  as they claim. Having had the experience of all my data being downloaded from my Mac without even needing a password left me feeling a bit sceptical about Apple's integrity. Having tried to ask one of the assistants about it, he sought to convince me that Apple products are 100% safe and impossible to access with the fire wall. I just felt sorry for him and thought he was a bit thick and obviously knew very little about the product or he thought I was thick enough to believe him. Why would you lie to people like that? Granted that I didn't have the most recently released Mac. Fourth annoyance is that I had spent ¬£1,200 on an iPhone Xs only to discover 4 months later that they would be discontinued. No one said that they would be discontinued at the time. What exactly is the deal with that? Are the phones so flimsy that they can only really last for 1 year and Apple wouldn't have to take responsibility for them when something goes wrong? How environmentally friendly is it that we are spending thousands of pound on Apple products that we discard after 1 year? What message are we sending to young people about being responsible? This is not sustainable.  Must we all feel pressured into having the latest iPhone, Mac, AirPods etc just to be better than the Joneses? As far as I can see, nothing ever changes with the phones anyway. Just add a few cameras on the back to make people feel self-conscious because their phone doesn't look like the latest one. My most recent experience at the Apple Store was that I went in, to try and get a diagnostic on an iPhone which had died suddenly. I was told to go away for 20 mins and then come back, which I did without complaint. I was told that the technician would be able to give the charging port a clean to see whether it would charge after that and if it does then it may be a problem with the battery so we can take it from there. Obviously my phone was dead so I could not receive messages. I returned approximately 25 minutes later to find that there were still at least 10 people waiting. My appointment had been cancelled.  However, the person who booked me in again did not do it properly. I was told before I went away that I may have to wait a little bit longer in the store when I returned so I waited. People who arrived after me were promptly seen by a technician. Employees stood around chatting but no one came to see why I was still waiting. I eventually had to ask one of the assistance where the technician was up to but she couldn't find me on the list of course. I was eventually seen by a snooty woman who looked very miserable indeed. She plugged my phone into a charger, said it was charging but I knew it wasn't because it had been like that for 24 hours. She asked another "technician" who didn't  know what it could be. He then said they couldn't fix it because it was discontinued in the store. I asked whether they have the equipment to run a diagnostic. No they wouldn't be able to do it.  I was going to wait for a few days to buy an iPhone 11 Pro but I think I might consider looking elsewhere. This is getting beyond disgraceful behaviour.

title: Case number 100900124694
text: Case number 100900124694.  My name is Warren P. I have been dealing with Tech support about a  damaged phone today. Asurion needed the phone reset to send us a replacement phone via the insurance we had on it. We could not get the phone reset because my son had changed the password. I was on the phone with your technician which was very pleasant and noligable. But we were unable to access the phone. She said we would have to go through a process that could take up to a month to complete. I elected to wait two hours to attempt to figure out the password. So she set up a call back from another technician in two hours. 1:45pm to call my cell phone. They have my cell #  I waited until 2:45 and I called Insurion to let them know I did not hear back from Apple. They decided to override the reset and send us the phone without it being reset. They advised I would get the phone on Tuesday. But shortly after they said they would send us the phone today and deliver it to us today. We would receive it between 5-7pm. I was blown away. At 6:30 a gentleman drove up to the house. Said he drove from Atlanta to our house in Morganton, Ga. An hour and a half drive. He set up the phone for us even. My son now has his phone for school tomorrow. I was very impressed with what Insurion did for us. Not so happy with Apple. I pay for three Apple phones for my wife, son and daughter. I have a Motorola Moto Z2 Force. I have to have a extended life battery because of we're we live. But I was going to try the 11 when it comes out. But after today. Being left hanging by Apple. I will not buy another Apple phone. I have upgraded the three other Apple phones over the past years. But I will not do it again. I am a business owner. If I set a appointment band not show up or at least call. I would get a bad name real quick. I did not get the call I was promised. Sad. Again they were to call my cell. And again this is the case number. 100900124694. I was told the the notes were there for the technician that was to call would have them. But again. No call. I'm not happy with Apple. I will copy this email and will more than likely post it on a review on the Apple web site. So what does Apple got to say about loosing a customer?

title: Don't expect to rely on Apple Support
text: Fingerprint recognition stopped on my iPhone SE at 9 months old.¬† I'd bought it in John Lewis and they were happy to fix it under warranty, but said they might have it for up to 28 days and as it is the controller for my hearing aids I could have been stone deaf for up to a month.¬† So I took it to the Apple store in Edinburgh who said that it would be fixed in a couple of hours.¬† I asked them also to deal with the fact that the phone will not link to iTunes and that, intermittently, the phone could not be switched off.¬†¬† The fingerprint sensor was fixed, although it took a bit longer than suggested, but not either of the other problems.¬† So I went back again, the switching problem was then said to have been corrected; no fault was found with iTunes....but they suggested I log a call to Apple Support (why if there was "no fault"?).¬† I did so, but by then had found that my phone now switched off (automatically, but not always) when the battery charge dropped¬†below 30%.¬† Anyway, I spoke for more than 30 minutes to an Apple expert who recognized the fault with iTunes.  Despite making the changes that he suggested we couldn't fix it and he suggested I return to the store....who should also be able to deal with the battery problem! If my hearing aids would work with Android I would revert to a trusty Samsung.

title: I had the worst experience in my life
text: I had the worst experience in my life. I bought an iMac on apple‚Äôs official website on Aug 20. I had it shipped to a Fedex package center and it arrived on Aug 26 (Mon). I was out of the country at that time so only picked it up on Sept 5. Since the first day of using it, it would freeze everyday even when there‚Äôs no program running. I brought it to apple store on Sep 10 (Tue) and was told I‚Äôm out of the return/exchange window. Since then I‚Äôve been with apple support online or in person at Genius Bar for 8 times with 8 different support staff, but the issue is not resolved. First, based on apple‚Äôs official website‚Äôs description of return policy ‚ÄúYou have 14 calendar days to return an item from the date you received it‚Äù I think I‚Äôm inside the window because I only physically received the item on 9.5. Even if you count from the day it is delivered, the 14th day should be 9.10 Tue, i.e. the day I went in to return it. Second, it is a new machine and there is problem since when I started using it, so it is either that the average apple user is expected to spend weeks debuging their new product before they can use it, or this is a rare event in which apple sold me a faulty product and should give me one that‚Äôs not faulty. Third, apple support is completely incompetent and irresponsible - I have spent a whole week working with various forms of apple support and it‚Äôs no where close to a solution. They are just sending me instructions that are obviously generic, i.e. not targeted at my problem at all, and so far none of them have worked. Every time I try a new method it wastes 6-8 hours of my work time, because it takes a long time for the freeze to occur. I‚Äôve been using apple product for 10 years and am really sad to see this is how Apple treats its loyal customers. I really hope Apple higher management could take notice and reach out to me to resolve the issue.

title: Worst customer service I‚Äôve ever experienced
text: The last two days with Apple support have been absolutely terrible. The epitome of bad customer service. In fact it would make a great case study for training in how not to do customer service.  The iPad Pro I bought in May was faulty. I contacted apple support to try and resolve the issue. Agent tried to solve it over chat, but not successful so set up an appointment with Apple Genius in Leicester. I went to appointment (had to wait quite a long time) and agent at the store tested the iPad. He confirmed that the usb c port was too big, hence to iPad not charging. Rather than give me a new sealed box, he gave me what he said was a new iPad and lead, as he said charger was fine.  I went home reasonably satisfied, despite a three hour round trip and paying ¬£3.50 for parking.  When I got home I tried to set up the ‚Äònew‚Äô iPad.  It failed to set up. I was pretty annoyed, but contacted support via chat again and spent ages going through stuff which didn‚Äôt work. Very annoyed by the end. Agent set up an appointment for someone to call me next morning.  Rachel called me at 8.15 am and spent best part of an hour going through resetting. It still didn‚Äôt work. I said I wanted a new iPad, and she said that I‚Äôd need to go back to Leicester to see if they could get it working, and if not they would give me a new iPad or refund me whichever I preferred. She said she‚Äôd send me an email to confirm this. So I did the 3 hour round trip with ¬£3.50 parking again, this time with my husband to support me.  Agent Tom said the replacement iPad I was given the previous day was NOT new, but a used spare. He also said he couldn‚Äôt give me a new iPad. I told him Rachel said I would be given a new iPad or a refund, and Tom said he couldn‚Äôt do that. I checked my email and saw that her email didn‚Äôt say I would be given a new iPad or refund. So she had lied to me.  I quoted the Consumer Protection Act to Tom and he said the manufacturer wasn‚Äôt responsible it was the retailer. He said he couldn‚Äôt  give me a new iPad, only another used one. So i asked for my original iPad back (which had only been replaced the day before) so we could go to PC World, as Apple had confirmed it was faulty. Tom said it wasn‚Äôt in the store any more. We suspect some other poor sap has been given it as a replacement and is probably now going through the same terrible experience as me.  Fortunately I had the email confirming my original iPad was faulty and had been replaced, so we drove for an hour plus to PC World in Grantham where I had purchased the original iPad. The chap at PC World was great and refunded us. I can only deduce that the reason I wasn‚Äôt signposted to the retailer straight away is that Apple know that they would have to refund / replace, and by stringing me along with shoddy seconds they may be able to avoid the cost.  If I had been told from the start that Apple wouldn‚Äôt be able to replace the iPad with a new one, I‚Äôd have gone to PC World straight away - it‚Äôs only 20 mins away from home and free parking after all. Instead I was strung along, told I‚Äôd been given a brand new iPad by two people then told it wasn‚Äôt new by Tom, told I would be given a replacement brand new iPad or refund by Rachel, then told by Tom I wouldn‚Äôt... As a long time Apple user and keen proponent of the Apple ecosystem, I am truly appalled by this experience. I have a MacBook Pro and iPhone, but when they are due for replacement am now considering Linux / Ubuntu. The Apple ‚Äòsupport‚Äô staff have clearly been trained well in dodging difficult questions and absolving Apple of responsibility. There was no attempt to offer recompense for the 8 plus hours I have wasted and fuel and parking costs I‚Äôve accumulated trying to resolve the issues. It has been the worst customer service  I‚Äôve ever experienced, and at 53 years old I‚Äôve suffered some pretty awful service. I have chosen to pay a significant premium for Apple products, yet the after sales service is worse than cheap scam companies.  It‚Äôs such a shame, as Apple‚Äôs products are generally great; this is the first issue I‚Äôve had in 10 plus years (other than accidents that have been my fault) and boy has it left a sour taste about the brand.  Definitely Bramley not Braeburn.

title: Awesome Apple Support Experience
text: My experience with Apple Support was awesome! And this second agent was able to get me my refund and they were extremely nice, she talked to me about my life and stuff and was super friendly and helpful. 5 stars well deserved, Apple Support.

title: Iphone 7
text: I have bought four iPhone 7‚Äôs over the past two years and out of these, two phones have developed problems without any fault of my own. The first phone developed a camera fault, preventing me from using the torch as well as certain apps. The second phone developed a hardware problem with the WiFi where I couldn‚Äôt use it with WiFi running without the iPhone going into a reboot loop.  Upon taking it to apple I was told there was nothing they could do and encouraged to buy a new phone instead of trying to repair my current one. They tried to claim that my phone was ‚Äúwarped‚Äù using an uneven apple bench which is of course going to be unreliable to test. In general I felt that my matter was not of concern to their staff and it was very frustrating since I have been a loyal apple user since the first few models of iPhone. To develop two hardware issues, in the iPhone 7 models indicates only to me that the apple build quality has declined since the days of the iPhone 5 which were much hardier phones.  Beginning to consider moving away from apple products after this extremely disappointing experience.

Basic & user friendly was what I loved about apple but I am extremely disappointed in their electronic ‚Äúprogress‚Äù thus far. Hope they keep us middle people in mind otherwise It‚Äôll be time to start programming my mind for an Android.

title: Man I wish I could leave ma poop as a‚Ä¶
text: Man I wish I could leave ma poop as a review, the screen starts to not work once I laugh, I swear, it‚Äôs programmed, maybe they found statistically that when a bad thing happens while someone is laughing, the anger increases and it increases chances of breaking the phone, just imagine if they increase phone breakings by 1% and assume they have 10 million customers that‚Äôs 100000 new phones sold to this bankrupt broke company pretending to be gucci

title: This is truly screwed up!
text: A while back, after an iTunes update, all my music disappeared. Not a big deal, I have it on my iPod, I'll just sync it. Today, I plugged in the trusty old iPod (15 years old and still works), and low and behold, all my music appears in iTunes. But it's grayed out. I try syncing/transferring  to iTunes but it won't work. I start a ticket with Apple and request a call. They call, the iPhone is in my hand, the call goes directly to voicemail, never rings. This happens 3 times. Phone in hand, never rings, goes to voicemail. I call them. The automated attendant does not understand that I ma not calling about the iPhone I'm calling from. 5 questions later, I get transferred to a real person. I explain to her what I want to do, she contacts s supervisor to get direction, comes back, explains how to move my music to my iPod, which is the reverse of what I am asking. I explain to her again, she consults a supervisor again, comes back and tells me it can't be done. I can't move the 1696 songs on my iPod BACK to iTunes because Apple does not go backwards. WHAT DOES THAT MEAN? I bought the music from iTunes on my laptop, I transferred it to my iPod (which at no time ever had the capability to purchase music), now I can't transfer it back to iTunes? I HAVE TO REPURCHASE IT? Ridiculous! With all the streaming services available, I will certainly avoid iTunes/Apple Music in the future.

title: APPLE IS DISGRACEFUL
text: Date of experience:   September 07, 2019

title: Terrible customer service
text: I have been a huge fan of Apple up until now. I had a MacBook Pro for 6 years that worked great. I have had multiple iPhones, iPads an Apple TV and an Apple watch. I have always had really good luck with their products. I purchased a MacBook Air last year and had no problems with it until yesterday. I opened it up and the screen was white with verticle lines going through it. I brought it to my local Apple Outpost store and they informed me that it was a hardware issue and it would cost approximately $600 to repair. I am 3 months past the warranty so Apple will do nothing to help. How can I spend over $1200 for a laptop to have it ‚Äúburn out‚Äù just over a year later?? This was not caused by something I had done, I was told sometimes they are just defective. Why should I spend another $600 to fix a problem completely out of my control. Apple says they stand by their products but clearly they don‚Äôt, if they did they would be a little more helpful. Even just meeting me halfway would be nice instead of basically getting told ‚Äúnot our problem‚Äù. I will never buy another Apple laptop again and instead of paying $600 to repair the one I have I will spend that money on a new laptop with a company that treats their loyal customers with a lot more respect.

title: Customer Service
text: Customer Service - don't make me laugh.  I swear Apple customer service staff are robots.  They all say exactly the same thing, show no emotion and are very, well let's be honest, disinterested in listening. I took in my ipad with an issue which turned out to be a faulty battery, and lo and behold I had to pay ¬£70 to get sorted.  Obviously my fault for buying an ipad with a faulty battery.  To solve the issue they gave me a replacement ipad, but like I said at a charge. Then 3 months later the replacement ipad develops a cracked screen which i had not dropped, was in a heavy duty shockproof case, but turns out my fault yet again. ¬£190 to replace screen, are you f****ing kidding me.  Asked to speak to a manager, who repeated, almost word for word what the 'technician' said.  They have a script and they stick to it. Robots the lot of them. Refrained from swearing or insulting them, just walked out and went to one of those wee shops that carries out Apple repairs for half the price. Amazing how Ipad make products where you can't just put in a replacement battery or replace the screen without major surgery or expense. Needless to say, I will never ever buy an Apple product again. After care - pants. Product durability - pants

title: Honestly
text: Honestly, ever since I switched to iPhone, it has been a better experience, compared to my history with Android. But there are some minor things that I would like to address. For example, when I ask Siri to look something up on YouTube, it doesn't use the YouTube app that I already have downloaded- it uses a browser and it makes it a little more difficult and somethings are not displayed properly because it's not on the app. I also mainly wanted to write a review about adding a little more variety to the Siri voices. I really think you guys should add more, (example: French and Middle Eastern accents and more)  lastly, another small thing. I really hope you guys can bring more customization to the text messaging chats: chat bubbles and font. Like, changing the colors and the font and stuff like that. I think that would be a lot of fun!

title: Loyalty treated with contempt
text: Having been a loyal Apple customer for 10 of the 12 years the iPhone has been in existence, I am now proud to have made the successful jump to Samsung.  Indeed you do get caught up in a web of products and get so deep in their ecosystem it's hard to get out, but it can be done. I am a techy and have always viewed Apple products the best of the best.  Not any more - when their Sapphire Crystal glass on the Apple Watch series 4 cracks at the smallest of bumps, and they treat you as an, and I quote, 'Apple Customer' rather than a person (this was how they addressed me in response to an official complaint), I was ready more than ever to switch providers.  In a way, Apple have done me a favour by selling me a duff 'toughened glass' watch and getting their impersonal robots to answer complaints, because now I have one of the best Android phones on the market and am discovering a whole new world of apps and tech that I could never have imagined in using Apple's stuff. I buy all my gadgets outright almost as soon as they're launched.  I have sold my iPhone XS Max but still have their Airpods, Apple TV, Macbook, iPad Air, iMac and Homepods.  I'll slowly be switching to alternative products for these but for now I'm happy I've moved to Samsung for my phone.  Hear it now people - Apple just don't care about you, they just want your money.  They claim to sell the best quality in their products but clearly don't.  I can't wait for the day when their business model begins to fail and is evident for everyone to see.  Needless to say they wouldn't do anything for me with my watch and said it was my fault.  I think they could look at each case on it's merits rather than have a blanket policy.  They could have made an exception for such a loyal customer.  Not happy Apple - not even interested in waiting for your next iPhone launch.

title: Apple customer service is awful!
text: Apple customer service is awful! They put all their efforts into sales not service. I upgraded my iphone, it failed completely after 2 months.  I went to the Apple store on Thursday, they could not look at it as too busy, advised go back next day ( an hour long round trip).  The next day they confirmed it was faulty/dead so agreed a replacement. None in stock, so would have to order one and I would get an email on Monday advising when it would be in store to collect.  Monday came and went. I will give them another day- then Tuesday came and went! I called via central numbers as no number for the local centre is available! They could not give me an update- no informatioon avaiolable to them!  Seriously, a tech company like apple, has to have people ring through from one country to another to see if anything has been done?  There is no system update they can check that tells them the status of the replacement order?? The first was a call from USA, I gave up after 35 mins being on hold, the frustation was too much! I tried again. The next call was to an 0800 number, turned out to be a guy in Athens, he again wanted to keep me on hold while he tried to ring my local store!  I was shocked! I asked for a call back & he reluctantly agreed to ask if someone from the store could call me back if he got through!!!! There website and systems are not customer friendly at all. Update, to top it off I just got an email with an apple customer support ID, it said  Apple Support- we are here to help. Click to re-open the case, so I did and it said "ID not found."  Useless! Another day has passed and I had to do it all over again as no call back! Eventually got the response that there is no replacement phone for me and it may take 7-10 days to get one!

title: We have purchased Apple products for‚Ä¶
text: We have purchased Apple products for years, but have lost all respect for Apple.  Sent ipad to Bright Star which Apple uses to evaluate trade ins.  Was to receive $70.  After a few days received an email from Bright Star saying there was obvious physical damage to the devicE, VALUE CHANGED TO $0. The damage was caused by Bright Star...prior to us accepting recycling of the item,  they altered the device.  We sent the item in like new condition...received back with engraved portion cut out and some white insert placed there...marks all over the back, evidently from prying off the back cover, and the ipad bent.  Apple or Bright Star take no responsibility and we are out $70.  Apple lost 2 loyal customers...use to think Apple was the best, but no more. BEWARE...AVOID APPLE AND DEFINITELY DO NOT USE BRIGHT STAR..... Update...complained to Apple directly re: Bright Star ruining our ipad, and yeap...Apple stands with the Scam company Bright Star and does not believe in its customers.  Obviously Apple believes it's okay for Bright Star not to pay us $70 for our ipad, but also okay Bright Star ruined our ipad by prying it open, cutting out a portion,  and bending it prior to our okay to recycle...was in perfect condition before Bright Star got a hold of it....SHAME ON APPLE...

title: Apple Watford and manager Jason appalling
text: Dear Sir, I logged by ‚Äòphone, a complaint, whilst standing in the Apple Store and standing next to the store duty Manager Jason commencing circa 4 pm this afternoon on Tuesday 27 August. Jason would not give me his surname or any further Apple ID. He accused me of being rude to him. I certainly was ‚Äòdirect‚Äô in my approach, but did not raise my voice or use any bad language. Apple‚Äôs whole ethos revolves around customer service. The service I received today, was recorded and was the worst I have ever received in a retail environment. It was arrogant, unfocused, unhelpful and incredulously poor. I purchased an Apple iphone XR, blue for ¬£799 in person at Apple Store, Intu, Watford on 25 April 2019. Strangely the service I received that day, was impeccable. A technician ‚Äòon hand‚Äô to download and change over my data from my old iphone 6. I have been having ‚Äòexperiences‚Äô of my new iphone   getting hot when it is processing, and on a visit to Devon at the weekend using ‚Äògoogle maps‚Äô, it got so hot that I could not hold it. It worried me as it would anyone. My first opportunity to return the product to store was today. Tuesday after the Bank holiday Monday. Jason the ‚Äòstore manager‚Äô / most senior staff member, apparently, took my enquiry. This is how it unfolded: 1) We don‚Äôt have any technicians here today (3.30pm) to have a look at your phone. 2) You can come in to a walk in tomorrow, with luck there ‚Äòmay‚Äô be someone to look at your phone. 3) Alternatively we could arrange a fixed appointment, but the earliest possible is Saturday. 4) I was extremely annoyed. Said I‚Äôd not paid ¬£800 to get no service. Said my business relied on the product. The product is under warranty. Expressed anger and annoyance; asked to see a more senior person. 5) Was told a more senior person ‚Äòexisted‚Äô but was not ‚Äòin‚Äô or ‚Äòavailable‚Äô 6) In the meantime another customer standing close by had come in and had clearly had a simple diagnostic check on their device, clearly without appointment. Several technicians were happily available when ‚Äòsales‚Äô took place. None could be found for me it seemed. 7) My round trip from home/business is 25 miles. My afternoon had now been wasted. When the ‚Äòphone was sold to me I was told to return in store ‚Äòat any time‚Äô with any problems and ‚Äòthey‚Äôll be sorted out immediately‚Äô. The Apple warranty is written similarly. 8) In ‚Äòutter disbelief‚Äô, I asked the same manager, as he stood in front of me for the apple help line number: 08000480408. I spent 1 hour and 14 minutes on that support line ‚Äòphone number in The Watford Store with this Store Manager Jason standing in close vicinity, watching this charade unfold. The two very helpful operatives at apple support centre/overseas, showed complete dismay at the way I was being treated. They raised a formal complaint as numbered above. They suggested this was all they could do in the circumstances. When I handed the ‚Äòphone to the store Manager, (three times), your call centre managers were similarly unable to get any common sense out of Jason. 9) The ‚ÄòManager‚Äô Jason made no effort to help or intervene. He even had the audacity to say to his colleagues over the ‚Äòphone that the store was ‚Äònow closing‚Äô. I‚Äôd arrived one hour and forty five minutes earlier. The Apple support members apologised continuously and profusely for their colleague‚Äôs behaviour. (Please listen to the recorded call). In addition your call centre colleagues even suggested I could, with their instruction do a diagnostic check with instructions over the ‚Äòphone myself. It didn‚Äôt work out‚Ä¶ , but, Jason standing by didn‚Äôt even offer his help. 10) Finally, I left the store having secured an appointment on Monday. As I left, Jason had the audacity to suggest to me that if ‚Äòmy problem‚Äô was ‚Äòso urgent‚Äô, I should take my chances and call in tomorrow morning, on the possibility a technician ‚Äòmay‚Äô be available. As I‚Äôm a pilot with a schedule I said no it won‚Äôt be possible. In the interests of safety, if the phone heats again, I will pop my sim card in my old Nokia analogue phone. Thanks Apple, you‚Äôve demonstrated a complete and utter lack of product back up. The staff in my business are almost certainly going to be changed over to other phones. Apple is expensive, because it is supposed to be well supported and guaranteed. This experience has been appalling. 11) Apple: I need my phone tested for safety reasons. I‚Äôve noticed it is not processing as fast as it did when I bought it AND it‚Äôs overheating. I also need to be compensated for a wasted afternoon, and the repeat trip which will be a further morning, I also need product repair/replacement if faulty. I also need to understand why you employ staff like Jason‚Ä¶ He has completely let the whole Apple Team down. He is a disgrace and should be disciplined. He‚Äôd have no place in my organisation, I would sack him without hesitation Yours Sincerely,

title: Look Out Seniors
text: As an 80 yr old woman with little technical knowledge - and having just had my husband pass away, I didn't need phone issues too.  An appointment to have the problems analyzed at the local Apple Store proved to me that the staff is trained to ignore the true needs of the customer and to lie as much as possible to sell, sell, sell. Short story: advised that a battery replacement would not fix all the problems that "might" be hidden and they supposedly looked up my account at Verizon and told me I was not eligible for a upgrade and that they were offering a new phone at the same price as Verizon.LIES.  Next falsehood: it will only take about 30 minutes to transfer data from old phone to new.  Two and a half hours later I walked out with a new phone that I was told couldn't accept all my personal texts from the old phone - so I lost pictures and comments regarding my husband and family - FOREVER. And it cost me almost $400!!  I told them about my loss and that I had another appointment in two hours when the first tech greeted me. That's another thing - I had four "techs" trying to get this transaction completed..and each one of them had to request assistance at every step.  My family is far more educated in this than I and they tell me that had I had an advocate with me, these "techs" would have never taken such advantage.  Look out seniors for Apple - be sure you take your grandson with you!  Oh, and to top it off -- I was eligible for an upgrade at Verizon - lesson learned - too late.

title: ECONOMICAL WITH THE TRUTH - GREED
text: I have an immaculate IPhone 5 that I use as a backup phone with an alternative sim.  When purchased it was the top of the range. A few months ago I asked about replacing the battery and the store said ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not worth it‚Äù and as they also stated they had no batteries in store I left as the phone was working fine for my needs. A few months on I noticed the battery was swelling so I contacted Apple who said they don‚Äôt support the phone and I should replace it. Fortunately I checked on the internet for more information and found a DIY fix was viable or for a sensible fee I could let someone else do it. I walked into a store yesterday and walked out with a fixed phone 15 minutes later and it only cost me ¬£32. The repair was done whilst I watched and was professionally undertaken. Apple could have served its customer but chose to pretend the item was scrap not even suggesting I use a readily available third party. I like the convenience of Apple hardware and am lucky I can afford it but as a matter of principal I no longer purchase until it‚Äôs a last resort because Apple no longer respects its customers.

title: Decline and Fall
text: Do you, like me, remember when Apple stores first came to the UK? Wonderful, wasn't it. Great products, great service delivered with enthusiasm. If White City is anything to go by, how times have changed. They're doing that thing I've read about - if you complain assertively they accuse you of being rude - apparently it's the new way of dealing with people who complain insistently and gives them an excuse to stop dealing with you. Having received the MacBook Pro recall due to potential battery problems I duly, by appointment, returned it to the store. Following replacement of the battery I returned to collect it and found they had damaged the casing (which they accepted). Getting this repaired was a marathon of inefficiency and wholly robotic responses. It's difficult to describe - all the right words were used by the person introduced to me as a "manager" but without any convincing conviction. The arrogance of Apple as an organisation, as represented to me, by this "manager" beggars belief. The inconvenience (and cost) incurred all as a fault of Apple and not even a gesture of compensation - not even to cover the most basic expenses - no surprise to me, now, that their revenues are falling. It's not even about compensation - a real appreciation of the incredible inconvenience I was caused and a REAL commitment to go the extra mile to minimise it would have been enough. I'll certainly think long and hard about replacements when the time comes - my love affair with Apple is over. What a shame!

title: Apple does not stand behind products.
text: I have had my beats for 7 months and they quit charging.  I called QVC and they said that I would have to contact Apple but they did not have the number.  When I expressed surprise she dug around and came up with a number.  I called Apple and they were very nice and sent me a box and I sent them for repair.  I received an email   Apple saying they were not under warranty - I called QVC and they said that the warranty was supposed to be for one year but there was nothing they could do.  I called Apple and they checked and said oh sorry they are in warranty for time but there is a piece missing.  I said nope I took the ear buds off as per your instructions- they then said they would look into and call me back in two days- they called me back the next day and when I didnt answer they sent emails saying I missed the appointment!!!! i called them back at the number on the email and it was invalid. I called the original number and they told me that a screen in the earbud was pushed in so it was damage not covered.  I asked them if this was the reason they wouldnt charge and they no but that it didnt matter as the pushed in screen voided the warranty regardless of the issue with them not turning on or charging. When i said that the earbuds were fine and that i could have received them with the screen pushed in and wouldnt know it as it did not affect performance they said they couldnt do anything about it- so sad out of luck.  Buyer beware on apple products. QVC and Apple just lost me as a customer.

title: SO sad and disappointed with Apple - after 16 YEARS!
text: Okay, I am torn here.......I have been an Apple customer, exclusively, since Mac OSX came out in 2003........however, I am now getting more and more exasperated by this company. Boy, do I miss Steve Jobs! For all his faults, at least there was an obvious strategy to his plans.......these days Apple make charges and changes almost at random!  PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE stop changing your connectivity all the time! Or if you must, then go all out for USB-C, like everyone else! I now have a briefcase with the lightest laptop (MacBook Air) and funky iPad, and lightweight keyboard, an iPhone8 .....and a whole section of cable and dongles to make them talk to all my older Apple stuff, and anything else out there! :-/  Did it never occur to you, Apple, that not all of the world has immediate access to superfast broadband all of the time? Or that we have loads of legacy (I used to call it "heritage". but no more!) APPLE stuff we still need to use? (if you force me to change, I WILL move to some other, cheaper, manufacturer - I do NOT like being bullied!)  My MacBook Pro is now virtually useless (yet the hardware is in perfect condition) due to repeated SW updates. I am at my wit's end with Apple - I REALLY don't want to move away, and I HATE MS Windows, but for everything else Apple do, I can find better / cheaper elsewhere..........and be very careful Apple, you may once have been the world's leading music supplier, but not anymore.........and once you've lost that, and your iPhone dominance, what's left? Oh yes, the Apple Mac, where it all started...........:-/

title: Apple also makes mistakes!
text: Like most of the other reviewers I have had Apple products for many years now. In April 2019 my iPhone SE (purchased in 2016) battery needed replacing, which was fair enough due to the age of the phone. I went to our local Apple store at the Bluewater Shopping Centre, Kent, UK and they replaced the battery for a fee of ¬£45.00 and a 90 warranty.  At the end of July 2019 I noticed the screen of the iPhone had started coming loose from the right hand side of the phone and was pushing up. I went back to the same Apple store with my concern. They said it was definitely a swollen battery, but as it was now out of warranty I needed to pay a further ¬£45 for a new battery, but that the phone needed to be sent away for repair. I was a bit taken aback that the replacement battery had only lasted 3 months and that Apple were totally unapologetic about it and quite adamant that a further ¬£45 needed to be paid. They sent the phone away and I got a loaner phone from them. BUT, what added insult to injury is that when the phone was returned from the repair centre I was charged ¬£125!!!! This was for a replacement battery and screen. At no point was I called or emailed to advise me that the bill would jump from ¬£45 to ¬£125, at no point was I asked if I wanted to go ahead with the repair or not! I was stunned at their assumption that this was ok and that I‚Äôd have the money readily available. The lady at the Apple store said she couldn‚Äôt knock off any money when I raised my complaint. She said the repair centre is a separate entity to them and I‚Äôd have to pay. Update -  I later raised my complaint via the ‚Äúhow did we do?‚Äù survey sent to me on email, and was called by one of the Bluewater Apple store managers the next day (Wednesday), who said he would look into it and come back to me in the next few days. By Saturday I still hadn‚Äôt heard back from him so decided to go back to the store. . . The manager on duty (not the person who called me) was very apologetic for the grand error and said I was only the second person he knows of that this has happened to. He also arranged for a full refund to show their regret, which I appreciate and was absolutely the right thing to do to from their side. Lesson: make sure your final repair bill is what you were quoted in the first instance!

title: Goodbye Apple.
text: I have owned iPhones and iPads for the last 12 years and upgrading every third year. In 2018 I purchased a new iPad pro 11" expecting this overpriced tablet to last a good few years, that wasn't to be. After 14 months of gentle use it gave up all signs of life and according to my local Apple store could no longer be repaired. Replacement was to be the only option for a mere $949 +tax. After lengthy discussions, no help could be offered from Apple.  After much thought decided upon a Samsung S4 Tab from Best Buy on offer for $350 and while I was at it a Huawei Mate 10 pro to replace my iPhone 7. I had now completely parted ways from Apple and of course iTunes.  Now after over 8 months of use I'm very, very happy to have changed both my phone and tablet for products that are as good as,if not better, and cost half as much as the Apple versions.  Last but not least. Yes, I have contacted both Samsung and Huawei customer care to get help and within minutes all questions were answered by friendly and intelligent staff. Certainly no Apple ' Take it or leave it' attitude.

title: AppleCare Advisors
text: Be aware that when you call an Apple store or Apple support of ANY kind, you are NOT actually speaking with anyone who works at or for Apple. You must go into the stores for that. Apple outsources its customer service to a company called Concentrix (who is currently being sued in the state of CA for major violations). Your call to the store gets rerouted to Concentrix, a company that employs people to work from their homes. This means any data you give Apple can be accessed by Concentrix employees who have no oversight. They can steal your data and the data of anyone in your household such as your address, credit card info, your child's info, etc and no one would be the wiser until it was too late and even then most people would not think of Apple as the culprit. Please note: Concentrix/AppleCare employees have ZERO hands on experience with Apple products unless they happen to own one personally. They are trained remotely for a few days then sent out to assist you. This is why they know nothing when you call for help. They put you on long holds because they are searching Apple's forums for a solution, something you can do yourself at Apple.com without putting your data at risk. Advisors use the same lines to make you trust them but they are following a script that requires them to use what are called the 3 A's (Acknowledge {the issue}, Align {with customer's feelings}, Assure {customer you can help}). Often, AppleCare advisors are taken from any of Concentrix's other client accounts like Nike or TurboTax then thrown on the Apple account almost as an afterthought. These advisors are so low on the chain-of-command they are not privy to releases until the public also gets it. Next time you call Apple, ask the advisor if they are working from their home or better yet, just listen to the background. There will be no noise like there would be in an actual call center. If you have an issue-go to the store itself or when an advisor answers, tell them to transfer you directly to the store. The way to get their attention and an appointment STAT is to use the words "hot" or "warm" when describing your device, even if it is not. Advisors are instructed to get customers to the store immediately if they hear those keywords. I hope this helps lift the veil of secrecy many company hide behind while their customers are left vulnerable.

title: I placed an order on 5/18/19 and tried‚Ä¶
text: I placed an order on 5/18/19 and tried to take advantage of the Barclay card 0% financing offer (that's in the checkout process).  Knowing I have fantastic credit and zero debt, I figured this would be approved instantly - it was not.  I had to make my purchase using an existing credit card all while taking an application hit on my credit report.  After going back and forth with Barclay‚Äôs, today 7/8/19, they approved my credit line and said go ahead now and make any apple purchases for the next 30 days.  Thats 6 weeks too late. I asked Barclays if they could do a transfer from my other credit card for the apple purchases - no - purchases had to be today forward. I asked Apple support - post sales - asked to do a return on my old credit card and charge it to the new Barclay‚Äôs (apple‚Äôs partner) card.  Apparently returns need to be within 14 days. So I‚Äôm left hung our to dry here.  It was Apple's process/offer/incentive to partner with Barclays, yet they failed to provide instant credit despite my amazing credit.  They eventually did after I provided them proof of a utility bill (!). I should have been able to take advantage of this incentive that lured me in and impacted my credit report as an inquiry and application. title: I bought an iPhone 7 plus about 8‚Ä¶
text: I bought an iPhone 7 plus about 8 months ago.  I splashed some water onto it next to the sink and wiped it dry with a cloth. I thought nothing more of it because Apple advertise it as waterproof to 1 meter deep for 30 minutes.  Oh dear - that was a mistake that was ! (a non-waterproof phone I would have turned it off and put it in dry rice for 24 hours).  However, shortly afterwards the phone stopped working and it was clear water had entered and was clearly broken. I took it under warranty to the Apple store. The response I got from the Apple store in Liverpool, UK was an absolute disgrace (Case ID: 100843874647).  Apparently, Apple do not take any responsibility for phones that prove not to be waterproof.  I was quoted that the phone is only waterproof to 1 metre depth for 30 minutes at the point of sale!  Therefore, presumably by the time you reach the shop door it is only 90cm for 28 minutes and after 8 months it is no depth for no time (i.e. not waterproof). Absolute disgrace!

title: I purchased the latest Macbook air and‚Ä¶
text: I purchased the latest Macbook air and quickly discovered that it is not good on the eyes. There has apparently been quite an uproar over the issue (based on online discussion), but the customer service representative I spoke to seemed unaware of the problem.  When I called Apple to ask what my recourse was (since the 14 day return policy had passed), I was told that a store near me was sometimes flexible in their return policy and sometimes accepted returns outside the 14 day period. This did not turn out to be case. So the customer service also wasted my time. I now have a $1,000 hunk of junk that I am even having difficulty selling online.  I now use my old MacAir--no problem. I will probably switch to a PC within the year.   How can Apple sell a product that is very obviously not good for one's health? This does not seem legal.

title: I've never had more issues with any‚Ä¶
text: I've never had more issues with any product like I have with apple. I brought in a mac laptop due to a powering on issue. The charging light was turning on but the computer wouldn't turn on. Brought to this Cerritos apple store to a technician who said he didn't find anything with it therefore had to be sent out for a flat rate of 500. Clarifies that no matter how small the issue it would be this amount and could only go up unfortunately if damages were bigger. I decided not to proceed as it was an older version and for that price it was just not worth it so what did I do? I made a HUGE mistake, I purchased a NEW LAPTOP! The old computer was then taken to a different personal technician who clarified it was just a false connection the power button was making. There was no replacement of any sort needed he fixed it right in front of me within a couple minutes with absolutely no charge and my computer worked like new. Don‚Äôt wonder why apple is such a big company with money this is the reason they don‚Äôt take responsibility for their damaged products instead they make YOU pay. A couple months later my beats are doing the same thing charging lights are on but won‚Äôt power. Brought them in and no surprise they want to charge a flat rate without knowing what the issue is AGAIN! I expressed my initial concern and dissatisfaction with the first scenario to "lead" Max who refused to provide his last name or employee i.d. He stated that the information provided to me the first time around with my laptop was "incorrect" I then expressed my concern in having the employee trained he said absolutely will and then I asked how will you do this again if you have no idea who helped me since you didn't care to ask for my serial # of my laptop? Point is if google troubleshoot cant solve your problem these techs wont either, they are basically trained to simply do basic reset steps provided by google.

title: As soon as I get my phone working again I am switching to Android
text: Everyone is super pleasant when you are buying something..... until you tell them that you do not remember your AppleID password. I was a different state on a business trip and my phone battery completely died and was no longer responding to a charger. I was actually within walking distance of an Apple store so I went on over expecting to get in, pay 50 for a battery, and get out. Unfortunately, I needed my Apple ID password in order to even start the process for some reason. After using touch ID for several years- of course I did not remember the password. Oh what a huge problem that was. Not only did the demeanor of the sales rep change to where he was talking down to me saying that it was my responsibility and he has done his part but I did not do mine, but he gave me little to no options of how this problem can be resolved. He told me pretty much to come back in 2 weeks when i have a password and we can continue...... By the way I was peaceful and polite the whole time and on the verge of tears while this man shows no sympathy and was dealing with me as if I had just threatened him. Anyway, I have no phone right now and I have another business trip flight in 3 days. I have no way to communicate with anyone and I am waiting for account recovery. I thought that maybe if I called and explained my situation that would help things. I got the SAME EXACT HORRIBLE TREATMENT on the phone once I told the representative that I did not have my password. At least she gave me more options of moving forward. She needed some code that is apparently written on the SIM card slot. It wasn't. So now I not only have a dead phone that I can do nothing about... I also have a jammed SIM card that I must get removed. I never thought I would ever say this.... but I am switching to Android as soon as possible. I will never be with Apple again. Never. The two individuals I spoke with were super rude, unprofessional, and merciless. It is very unreasonable to leave people without a phone for ANY length of time just for a dead battery. Absolutely ridiculous.

No help from apple there. Just a you could try another store or buy another computer. Apple is going down hill fast. I paid a premium for junk.

title: Overall I‚Äôm happy with apple but with‚Ä¶
text: Overall I‚Äôm happy with apple but with the new design on the AppStore I‚Äôm not sure what‚Äôs free anymore and what‚Äôs not. My card is connected to my App Store and I just clicked ‚Äúget‚Äù on an app that I‚Äôve been told is free (tasty) and it just said your payment has been confirmed. Since when are you allowed to charge people for something that A they don‚Äôt know they‚Äôre being charged for, B not specifying a price beforehand.  I really hope I wasn‚Äôt charged!!

title: I used to love Apple
text: I used to be an avid Apple supporter. One look at my devices would tell you that. I‚Äôve been using Apple since I was old enough to understand what e-devices were and to date I‚Äôve had three iPads, three iPhones, two iPods and an Apple Watch. And I‚Äôm not even the biggest Apple fan in my family.  But I‚Äôm honestly this close to switching. Apple has begun putting in updates that make their software needlessly difficult to use. If there is one thing I cannot stand it is feeling out of control and completely helpless to try and understand what the f*** is going on. Additionally, everything is now automatically put on the cloud. And we have no way to stop it. I have a serious data struggle and do not want to have to download my books from the cloud over and over. But alas when I tried to turn off iCloud for iBooks all my files disappeared with it. Even the ones I had re-downloaded. This is a load of bull. Itunes on my pc no longer recognizes my iPhone 8 but it auto downloads all my music without asking permission. Another drain on that very limited internet access I mentioned. Additionally, my cloud is now full with s*** I never wanted there in the first place and the wonderful Apple platform is consistently trying to bully me into upgrading my storage for the *low low price of one kidney.* please note not actually but I‚Äôd probably have to sell a kidney to afford this nonsense. I bought the phone with the bigger storage capacity SPECIFICALLY for this purpose and now I‚Äôve had that option taken away from me. I‚Äôm tired of this platform being made so difficult to use that the ‚Äòfriendly‚Äô is gone from user-friendly and I would like to have control over my device and how it stores things returned to me. Feeling very disillusioned and honestly hope Apple realizes how fast they‚Äôre losing customers and that they cannot actually afford to f*** us around like this because they aren‚Äôt actually all that great or leading the market or whatever. They‚Äôve become a bunch of exclusivist a**holes and when even your loyalists start becoming disillusioned you must know that you‚Äôre taking it too far. 98% chance my next phone with not be an Apple.

title: Apple has the worst customer service

title: Spent nearly 3 hours on chat  as I am‚Ä¶
text: Spent nearly 3 hours on chat  as I am being chaged a monthly icloud storage fee that I did not authorise. When I try to remove the subscription it says I don't have any, when I try to request a refund it says I don't have any transactions and sends me in loops around the website. When I try to remove my credit card apple prevents me saying that I have an active subscription.  Agent tells me I have to turn off icloud on my phone but I no longer have the phone as it broke just out of warranty and no longer charges even with 2 new batteries fitted so cannot be turned on due to no charge ever... Ask to remove my credit card no less than 6 times and was refused, illegal and breach of gdpr. Asked icloud to be removed as subscription, apple said they couldnt have an agent qualified to do it. Asked for a refund of the unauthorised fees taken, told nobody can do that either. 3 hours going in circles, support agent Travis rude and unhelpful, as were the other 3. Rang my bank and told apple have set up a recurring payment not a direct debit so cant even cancel it. Have had to cancel my card and reported it to my banks fraud dept, as apple give no means of opting out of this so called subscription, that one of apples agents made me signed up to in the first place to try and backup my data when my phone broke but never worked as it took so  many hours and never did finish a single backup so ran out of battery and phone no longer turned on. All in all the worst experience ever , and think blocking customers into a subscription they dont want and illegally holding their credit card information hostage is so messed up. Unbelievable, and yet completely factually accurate.

text: I have used Apple support several times and they have always provided decent service and advice.

title: The Apple has a Worm.
text: My latest experience with Apple was a complete disaster. I called Apple Care for service, and the service was less than caring. They did not honor their commitment. I wasted a lot of time on the phone and for nothing. The experience was horrible. Not only will I never buy another Apple product, but I will tell everyone and their mother about my experience. Apple has changed. They used to be a great company. I recommend that if someone has absolutely no other choice; being a significant financial burden to switch to PC, to buy refurbed and run from Apple Care. It is simply not worth the money. If switching is an option, consider other options. When Steve Jobs was CEO of Apple, the company was great; at least from a consumer's perspective. Today, they are far less caring. The equipment is far less reliable, and the customer service rep is far less able to resolve problems. The representative tried her best to help me in all fairness, but Apple policies tied her hands. She is a manager in a multiple $billion dollar company and could not make an $80.00 decision. I don't blame her at all, and thank you for trying Wendy. I blame Apple and its lack of commitment to After Sale Service, which is what makes the difference between one-time customers and repeat customers. I will not spend another dime on an Apple product. S.Carter Vancouver, WA

title: Apple's keyboard program is a fake
text: Apple has declared a keyboard replacement program, however it is just a declaration. I regret I ever tried to have my MacBook pro 2016 keyboard replaced. Though it is supposed to be under the program, they will always find an excuse not to replace it. I have an issue just like it's written, with some keys printing double, so I had to correct every time what I was writing, and of course with a password it is becoming really tricky... However the "authorised repair center" of Apple said it is due to water damage, though I had never any water damage. They did not provide any proof of that, they just took some pictures of the outside, with some marks on it, - which have nothing to do with a keyboard at all. When I called Apple - though it is their authorised repair shop - they said they take no responsibility for their actions and are not going to help me at all. This is the Apple expensive service for which we all pay when buying their stuff. So no Apple for me, from now on (though I have already a lot of stuff from them at home).

title: Worst customer service of any major‚Ä¶
text: Worst customer service of any major retailer I have dealt with.  I bought the Airpods (my second pair) in February.  They are advertised to be amazing for listening to music and working out.  The first pair I had got corrosion on the mesh at the bottom of the earpiece a little over a year after I purchased them and Apple told me they were out of the year warranty so there was nothing they could do.  I really liked the features and functionality of them so I purchased another pair.  3 month in I have corrosion again.  The Apple store told me "they look like they water corrosion on the bottom, so that voids the warranty".  BS!!  I travel all over the country for work.  All I do is where them on the plane and to workout.  If anything, it is sweat, and if they are going to sell a product for $150, it better last longer than 3 months of working out.   Horrible service and not standing behind their product.

title: Apple AirPods
text: Apple AirPods My main reason for my buying AirPods was to be able to use them on the move to make voice memo notes, which is when I get my best ideas.  The quality of the reproduction with the AirPods is so poor, however, that they are not worth using for this purpose.  They work well for calls and music, which I guess is their main function but if you expect to use them to make voice memo notes don't bother if there's the slightest bit of background noise you'll hear intermittent grunting, and that's about it.

title: Apple: bad performance on several levels
text: Apple: bad performance on several levels A few months after buying that MacBook Pro, the keyboard started not working properly. Now it stopped working completely. Also the touchpad starts having problems now. Extremely bad performance for a product in this price range.   To get it repaired I was told to do a backup: external hdd doesn‚Äôt work, the MacBook wants to format it and delete all that I have saved on it. A friend had compatible hdd but even that didn‚Äôt work. Now I bought iCloud storage to store the data and do the backup and finally get this horrible product fixed but apple does not fail to disappoint again: I bought 2 tb of cloud space and have not uploaded anything from the MacBook yet and it tells me it is full.  Customer support? Non-existent. Scheduled a phone call at 18.15, at 18.30 still no one was available.

title: I was having a problem redeeming my giftcard
text: I was having a problem redeeming my gift card I was speaking to an agent and was cut off. I eventually called back about 10 minutes later and ended up speaking with Shenika. She is an awesome sales Rep as well as very helpful and relatable. She wasn‚Äôt aloof at all and though she was business-like she was also friendly, helped to dissipate my irritation at trying for over an hour to redeem a gift card to no avail and she was just awesome. She put through my order gift card balance included and had me happy and on my way in no time. Shenika deserves 2 thumbs up as a sales representative because I feel that the issue she helped me solve was a technical support issue but she did i it.  BTW the automated robots need to learn to follow instructions

title: Unnecessarily Rigid Security
text: Great, until something goes wrong. Apple takes an extremely rigid stance toward security. I appreciate due diligence, especially when more folks are using ApplePay et al, or if you have terrible people who are trying to get into your phone or something. My qualm is not in the level of security, but how inflexible it is. In my case, I downloaded a work-related app on my personal device that required me to change my iPhone's passcode last Thursday. I found the app's demand odd, and at first thought it was prompting me to create a passcode for just that app. I use Touch ID 99% of the time to access my iPhone, so did not catch the newly created passcode was in fact that for my entire phone until one morning my iPhone prompted me for my passcode over and in lieu of the usual Touch ID. From here it was game over; despite full knowledge of all my credentials and a valid Touch ID, I could not remember the last 2 digits of the new 6-digit passcode. I tried multiple times to no avail, tried in vain to back up my phone using my MacBook (it wouldn't let me without unlocking the device, read every article and contacted Apple Support, who told me recovery was the only option. There was no 2-factor authentification or using any of my other credentials to work around this; it was passcode or bust. Well, I don't pay the extra money for cloud storage of my photos, so over a 6-digit Thursday mistake I lost so many family photos I can't get back. I understand forgetting the new passcode is my fault. But I wish there had been some flexibility or mercy, an opportunity to provide the 99% authenticating security information I did have. This has been a really disappointing and scarring Apple experience.

title: Apple charged my card for $300 dollars‚Ä¶
text: Apple charged my card for $300 dollars after they gave me one price for my phone and decided my trade in value wasn't that value. They told me my new phone would be $599. They had said my battery was swollen OR screen was lifting on my old phone but no definite answer. They also said they my 7 plus wasn't actually a 7 plus. They sent the phone back and charged me $300 on top of the $599. They also were supposed to contact Verizon and let them know my new device agreement was with them. That didn't happen either and Verizon is still charging me for the phone that apple charged my account $300 for! They then tried to tell me that the only resolution was for me to send everything back to them and then they would give me my money back. Take the 7 plus to some store, pay to get it repaired and then they would try the trade in value again. What the hell!? I explained that i'm a small business owner and that doesn't work for me because I run my business entirely from my phone. I was on the phone for 3 hours with them. 3 hours! All i wanted was the $300 back that they charged my account for because the inital agreement was for $599. Had i known that my phone was going to be valued at 0 dollars and then charged $300 on the back end I WOULD HAVE NEVER PURCHASED THE DAMN PHONE! Now they want me to be without a phone "while i figure it out" and tried to paint it as though they were doing me a favor. I DID NOTHING WRONG I haven't even addressed the fact that they STILL haven't contacted VERIZON to let them know that I paid them $300 dollars for a phone that Verizon is STILL CHARGING ME FOR. So on top of paying for my new phone, im still paying Verizon for my old phone and I paid Apple $300 for a phone that they said, later on, had no trade in value and wasn't actually a 7 plus WHEN IT IS! And i'm supposed to be happy with a resolution that COMPLETELY inconveniences me!? I want my $300 back because I was told it was going to be one price and then I got charged on the back end. I want to be able to keep my damn phone that i'm already paying for and not have my life and my ENTIRE business inconvenienced over something THAT WAS NOT MY FAULT I want them to contact Verizon like they said they would so I can stop paying Verizon AND Apple for the same phone.

title: Absolutely disgusting customer service and appalling failures in software
text: I have an iPhone 8. The touch ID pad broke despite gentle use, so I disabled the touch ID facility in settings (going back to using the passcode). Still couldn't get into apps, my keychain passwords and so on - it still demanded Touch ID, despite this being disabled. Called my phone provider (3) - who were helpful - phone under warranty. Called Apple - after several calls going up the chain-of-command, their senior tech team remote accessed my phone and confirmed that I should be able to use, and access, everything by disabling the touch ID (which I'd done) and using my passcode alone. Then they confirmed, by utilising remote access, that the Apple 'floating home button' workaround does indeed NOT ACTUALLY work as advertised - the phone STILL demanded my Touch ID to access anything, despite this function having been disabled. A week later, still not able to access anything by other means (no other working Apple devices), they've informed me they're sending the phone back, still broken, as I hadn't paid the ¬£445 to have it fixed. I was TOLD it was an internal 'unexpected' Apple coding issue as the floating home button should work, and that there would be no charge for any repair - I don't even care if Touch ID pad is replaced or not - fixing their own workaround with the floating home button and passcode SHOULD work, or what's the point? No email was sent demanding a payment, I'm at the beginning of a two year contract and when my work manager called herself to complain, a senior manager actually LAUGHED at her down the phone. No complaints department exists. This company is rotten to the core and has NO interest in customers whatsoever.

title: Bad certified battery replacements
text: Took 2 iPhone 6S‚Äôs in for battery replacement the end of 2018 to take advantage of $30 replacement.  One phone began to shutdown random and have failed battery just days past 90 day warranty. The replacement was made at authorized repair center since we are 3 hours from apple store. The repair center was still 1 1/2 hours away. I contacted apple support who uploaded diagnostic files from my phone. The technician said the battery was definitely bad and should have lasted longer. A day later the support team told me to take it back to repair center. I explained the 1 1/2 hour drive and that I needed to know it would be taken care of. They never replied. I went to repair center. They agreed that my new battery was bad, but would not repair it for free because they said apple would not reimburse them for parts beyond 90 days. I got charged $80 to get this defective battery replaced. I sent apple support an email telling them what happened along with my wasted 1 1/2 drive. It has been complete radio silence. So I believe apple thought the repair center would cover the cost. The repair center knew apple would try to stick them with it. In the end, the customer got stuck. Two lessons learned. 1. Apple‚Äôs declining iphone sales has caused them to become predators on the service side. Not, a top choice in the next phone replacement for my family. 2. Their requirement to use only apple certified repair centers or apple store is a joke. People should just take their chances with other reputable repair places if they are more convenient to get to.

title: APPLE - the new scammers in town
text: apple is not what is used to be anymore. not to mention the quality of its products is decreasing, and i mean the iPhone and mac book. my recent experience with apple trade in is making me think of Apple as scammers.  here's my experience. i signed in on Apple site and followed all the procedures of trading in my mac book air for a new one. i got a quote of $180 for my old one. i did all that they asked me to. my laptop was working normal and fine. i mailed in to the site apple told me to.  a week later i receive an email stating that my laptop had lines going thru the screen, and my new trade in quote was $55. i called apple and the representatives i spoke to said they have nothing to do with the quote or my product and that i needed to contact the Phobio company who was handling my return. Yet when i filed my trade in order was on apple website, the quote was from apple website, and not once was this company Phobio mentioned as part of my trade in process.  Apple swiftly washes their hands ,and refused to further discuss my issues. Would i have known is not Apple directly handling my trade in i would of have done more research into the credibility of this Phobio company. As i was explaining my disappointment and dissatisfaction to an apple customer service manager Mr. Sergio Solano , he also gave me the number to contact the Phobeo company yet said he will be there with me every  step of the way to assist and make sure i am happy.  he said he'd call me back. he has not gotten back to me. i called him several times as this Phobeo company says it really is Apple who is in charge of the prices of trade ins as well as getting my money back. Yet i feel like a ball being tossed back and forth between Apple and Phobio without any of them taking responsibility to pay me what i was quoted for my macbook air which worked perfectly when i mailed in to them.  Now even if i get my laptop back from them i am doubting it's the same conditions computer  i sent them because when i mailed it to them directly from the apple store my computer worked fine, yet at their office they claim it's making lines. What a disappointing experience. I've been using Apple products for the passed 17 years. I've done trade in's before with Apple and i never had this experience.  Which leads to the confirmation that Apple Products and Apple Service is not worthy and not the quality i came to respect and be loyal to for the passed 17 years. title: Unsatisfied Champion of Apple
text: Let me start off by saying that I am one of your people. No, I do not work for Apple but I might as well as I am a champion of your products. I work in the small business technology consulting industry (help desk support is a large part of it).  I sit here on my MacBook Pro with my iPhone XS Max, AirPods, iWatch, iPad and my iMac is in the other room.  I am everything Apple and I purchase new all of the time. Therefore, the trade in is critical to me staying current and wanting to keep buying your new products. I recently purchased the newest iPad (over a grand) and traded in my not-so-old iPad.  It was estimated at $400 trade in which was great. Helped me justify a 1K iPad purchase. I received an alert that the iPad had a bend in the frame (a known Apple defect - as I did not bend it) and they took off $50 from the trade in. However, your trade in partner claims they told me the trade in value was $0 and that I "accepted it."  I whole heartedly would never have accepted $0 for a relatively new, good working iPad.  Even if I did accidentally accept $0 (which I know, whole heartedly I did not), there has to be something you can do to assist me. I feel as if I have been robbed of $400.   I will say that the agents I spoke to on the phone were excellent and this is not reflective of their level of support. This is a flaw in the trade in system. I don't know what I want here. I'll either take my old iPad back and sell it on my own or I'll take the credit that I am rightfully owed. If this is not resolved, my whole foundation and love for Apple will severely be compromised.

title: Apple repair service - Just a waste of time?
text: I recently damaged the face of my Apple watch and got in touch with Apple to get it repaired, I told them that the face was scratched and the guy said it would need to be assessed by the repair team, which I thought was reasonable.  I got an email saying that they would pick up the watch. I also, the same day, got an email saying that based on what I had told them the watch would be repaired under warranty, which I thought was excellent.  When the repairers assessed the watch they said that I would have to pay ¬£238.70 + Tax to get it repaired because there was damage that I had not mentioned in the original repair request and included a photo of the scratch that I had told them about. I immediately contacted them and explained that this was not the case and directed them to the transcript of the conversation as provided by the guy that I had the online chat with. They said that if I had phoned them instead of talking to the online adviser they would have told me that the repair would not be covered by the warranty. I was initially prepared to pay to get it repaired but was shocked and disappointed at the way they went about it (especially after being told that it would be repaired under warranty). Apple have now closed the repair request and are sending the watch back to me. Just a waste of everyone's time as far as I'm concerned.....or is it more a case that once they have your device they think you might just pay what they ask? Does a company like Apple really have to resort to these kind of tactics to make money? or are the top bosses oblivious to what's going on at ground level?  Anyhow I'll probably shy away from their products and services from now on.

title: Concerning Apple ITunes:
text: Concerning Apple ITunes: Using a free version of an app, I inadvertently hit the Home button as I moved my finger across a banner scrolling at the bottom of the screen and accidentally purchased a year-long subscription.   I tried canceling the subscription and it looked like it went through but Apple reversed the decision since the purchase was declared "ineligible" for cancelation per their new Terms and Conditions.  I pleaded with them, as a matter of good policy, to defend the consumer in a situation like this, but they declined.   A company with an ounce of integrity would do the right thing in this situation, so we are left to judge Apple by its actions in this particular case.  Word to the wise:  safeguard yourself against accidental purchases or suffer the same outcome as I did.  I've now gone through my credit card to support me in declaring the charge void but am not expecting to be greeted any differently. And why should anyone do business with a company that is becoming increasingly hostile to consumers and won't defend their rights in a simple case of accidentally tapping the wrong button?

text: Date of experience:   April 18, 2019

title: A very unhappy iMac customer.
text: Apple have just run me through the wringer for three straight days ‚Äì an all-round miserable customer experience. Over the last 10 years, my wife and I have equipped ourselves with a range of Apple devices, having been attracted by their ease of integration, and the simplicity of transitioning from one device to another when replacing them. But this recent experience has made me reconsider this. I just replaced a 6 year old iMac (a desktop Mac) with another, new iMac. What was supposed to be a very straightforward migration of data, applications and settings from one machine to another turned into a nightmare. After a full day of failed migration processes followed by successive calls with Apple support staff (many of who were quick to lay all blame at my feet and couple of whom added to the aggravation by dropping their calls), finally a senior level (tier 2) Apple advisor determined after consulting with several of his colleagues that the issue stemmed from a botched warranty repair on the original iMac (replacement of the screen when it failed a few months after purchase). It turns out that the Apple repair crew had used an unorthodox work around when they put in the replacement screen. After finally identifying the problem, it was also confirmed that this work around was a ‚Äòdone-deal‚Äô and we could not set up the new iMac with the normal migration process drawing on the data, applications and settings ‚Äì either from the old iMac itself or from the backups on our Apple AirPort Time Capsule. We then set about taking the data and applications a file at a time from the most recent Time Capsule back up ‚Äì a laborious process and somewhat nerve-wracking as one is having constantly to double check you got everything and one is never quite sure. And there were numerous glitches and retracing of steps required. And for three days I had to put the rest of my agenda on hold with successive calls, screen share sessions and waits for call backs from Apple staff. There were a couple of the Apple tech support people who were particularly helpful and were also quick to recognize Apple‚Äôs part in creating these issues. But I wish I could say this of all the many Apple staff I spent time with over these three days.
